intro: Dactylorhiza occidentalis, commonly known as the western marsh orchid, is a member of the orchid family (Orchidaceae) and is native to Europe and parts of western Asia. It is a terrestrial herb with a short, erect stem and typically produces 2–6 showy, pale purple to pink flowers. The plant has a fibrous root system and thrives in wet, calcareous habitats such as marshes and damp meadows. Its flowers are borne on a single, leafless stem and are characterized by their spurred lip. Dactylorhiza occidentalis is known for its ability to hybridize with other Dactylorhiza species, contributing to its genetic diversity.
